Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Low-Power, Wireless Crop Quality Sensors for Grain Quality Preservation and Storage Automation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to increase the returns of grain storage for farmers and reduce overall postharvest loss due to toxin and insect damage. Ten billion bushels, over half of US grains, are stored on-farm each year for 3-12 months. During this period, grain is susceptible to spoilage, infestation, and moisture loss?all of which impacts the price a farmer receives at the time of market delivery. There is no easy way to monitor grain quality changes throughout the storage season to optimize for best times to run aeration controls to preserve, condition or maintain the grain. This leaves farmers with a ?gut check? system of driving to each grain bin site and climbing up and inside units. Since grain is priced based on moisture baselines, farmers are essentially selling water and weight, their final price outcome can vary significantly based on how well they managed grain conditions throughout the storage period. In the US, an annual $3 to $ 5 billion dollars (3 ? 5%) of crop value is lost due to toxin, insect and moisture mismanagement that could be prevented through the introduction of affordable and accessible monitoring technology.

The proposed project would advance internet of things automation and wireless sensor applications as applied to production agriculture and the postharvest supply chain. There are certain, manual processes of farm production that are strenuous due to time burdens and the lack of obtainable information to make decisions. Monitoring grain assets, the product of farmers? toil and the safety net of global food supply, in farm bins, commercial storage, and barges is one such process. Sensing for when loss and spoilage risks occur, but more importantly connecting and turning the data into automation opportunities before they exist is the aim of this proposal. Cable-based monitoring solutions exist, but adoption is restricted due to physical installation limitations, electricity/power constraints, and investment costs. This project will validate the feasibility of a low-power, wireless sensor that can detect grain conditions and last a full postharvest cycle (18 months). Such a device will create opportunities to track grain qualities across the agriculture value chain, beginning with its use to monitor and automate farm grain storage. By characterizing, and testing against cable systems and within grain science 3D models, this project will prove the wireless sensor?s direct functionality within this first farm application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: Iowa State Research and Demonstration Farms

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support of the National Science Foundation’s SBIR Phase I funding, Amber Agriculture was able to specify, manufacture and test the feasibility of kernel-like sensors for grain management.  The primary outcome of this project was finalizing the product and obtaining the industry-certified stamp necessary for introducing the technology in the commercial supply grain supply chain. 

 

Temperature and moisture are critical quality metrics for how cereal grains conditions are measured, maintained, and eventually priced in the marketplace.  The ability to track, understand, and make decisions on timing moisture metrics as grain is stored and moved across the supply chain will lead to increased profitability for farmers and commercial handlers.

 

Each year, global cereal grain loss is estimated to be 5% for developed and 7% in developing nations.  If accurate, this equates to $10+ billion annual loss across global corn, wheat and soybean products alone.  Specifically, in the US, farmers are leaving approximately $1 billion on the table from over-drying grain due to mismanagement in grain storage, while also facing a $1.7 billion risk from under drying leaving exposure to insect and toxin damage.  This $3 billion, too wet or too dry seesaw is felt in the individual farmer’s economics from the time of filling grain storage at harvest to delivering it to market in later months.  Legacy technology for monitoring grain in storage has included cable-based offerings.  These solutions require costly installation by a technician whereby the internal support structure of the grain bin is rebuilt, and costs on average $8 - $12K per bin.  Roughly 10% of the 500,000+ onfarm grain bins have invested in these types of solutions.  From our research, the bottleneck for greater adoption of monitoring comes down: system install and price. 

 

At the farm level, Amber seeks to introduce low-cost, practical tools to help US farmers manage grain.  Farmers face two primary challenges: knowing the conditions of grain throughout the 3-18 months they store it onfarm, and deciding when to run aeration systems at grain bins to condition effectively. 

 

Amber’s development goal is to introduce a plug-and-play, self-installable grain monitoring product with a one-year payback period.  This led to our interest and exploration of validating the feasibility of affordable one-time use sensors, that could be easily implemented, last the length of one-storage season, and be recycled after its effective use to the farmer.  The kernel sensors would communicate to cloud software, and connect with a control box to initiate aeration systems based on peak weather conditions, the grain’s current state, and the farmer’s expected delivery date.              

 

The functional requirements of the sensor included a mechanical design that could withstand flowing through postharvest equipment and novel low-power wireless network that could transmit data through a grain mass and last the length of multiple month storage season.  Through this proposal, Amber demonstrated the functional potential of small sensor nodes, randomly distributed in a grain mass, communicating through a wireless network.  The core outcome of the project was finalizing the product and obtaining the industry standard certification for dust proof, explosion proof (Class II, Division 1, Group F and G under UL 913 and CSA 60079-0, 11) which allows Amber to begin commercial sales.

 

In addition to a certified kernel-like sensor, Amber finished the self-install hardware pieces of the gateway modem that captures and sends sensor intel into cloud software and the fan controller which is wired into aeration systems to enable software control.  Bundled together, Amber has the pieces for a closed-loop, automation system to help farmers manage grain in a bin.

 

The broader impact of this research includes the societal interests of metric-verified food supply chains.  Interests that stem from a growing demand for products with carbon-understood footprints, country of origin knowledge of ingredients, and a variety of other hard-to-measure sustainability definitions that could vary from person to person.  All of these trends will create opportunities for more niche, specification rich marketing opportunities for food entrepreneurs and established players. 

 

With Amber’s technology Farmers will be empowered with tools that can provide efficiency and profitability gains, while also positioning them for growth opportunities that may arise out of food tracking trends.
